TEXT.English: [TAB]Arturus found his friend by candlelight. Torches were forbidden in this hallowed chamber, deep in the Underhome. The soot and smoke they gave off obscured the runes carved into the rows of pillars, covering the names and deeds of the honored Dwarven ancestors. The ancient dwarves who kept these sites, carving new stories and teaching others to read them, were called Runewardens officially but 'Hand Seers' more commonly. Squinting in the candlelight so much invariably robbed them of their sight, so they learned every word and letter by hand. Kandros Fir was at the end of his Clan's section of the Rune Hall, chisel in hand.[PARAGRAPH:1]"I knew I'd find you here," Arturus said, kneeling next to him.[PARAGRAPH:1]"I was his closest kin. I must add his name and deeds to our story."[PARAGRAPH:1]"Of course, old friend. But that isn't all you are planning, is it?" Kandros bowed his head.[PARAGRAPH:1]"I am loyal to our king, by my bones, I am loyal."[PARAGRAPH:1]"But?"[PARAGRAPH:1]"I can no sooner abandon family than fall on my own axe! Suppose your cousin Grunnos was missing. What would you do?"[PARAGRAPH:1]Arturus snorted. "Speak not of that wastrel, but be glad he has many older brothers to be king before him should good Kanlore pass."[PARAGRAPH:1]"But?"[PARAGRAPH:1]"But... were his fate that of Luach, I should dig to Mammon's hell if it would find him. But not if my king forbid it! I know the bonds of kinship, but what of kith? Do you abandon your duty and your friends for a mad search? The winter will take you too, and what will that accomplish?"[PARAGRAPH:1]Kandros rose, placing the hammer and chisel back on the altar as he turned to leave. "My duty has others to attend it, and my friends as well, dear Arturus. But Luach Fir is alone. If our friendship has meaning to you, you will not hinder me."[PARAGRAPH:2]It had not been easy getting to the surface. No one had been allowed to leave since Kandros' cousin Luach had gone to study the surface. Winter still raged, as it had for more than six generations, but young Luach was undaunted, and had petitioned Kanlore for leave to explore the harsh surface regardless of the danger. Supplies were slim in the Underhome. Their stores of black powder had been exhausted so long ago that the last Dwarves who would even recognize it had passed away, and expansion of the Underhome was tedious work with pick and hammer. Spices had run out early in Kandros youth, and the pork and tubers his children fed on left eating a chore. So Luach had at last been allowed to take another appraisal of the state of the bleak surface, but Kanlore's hesitancy had been proven right when Luach did not return for months. No one was permitted to leave now, meaning Kandros had to sneak past guards in the dark, and would be ill regarded if he returned at all.[PARAGRAPH:1]The exit to the Dwarven home was sealed with a massive stone door, and Kandros exhausted himself prying it open, even using his pick as a lever. He bravely stepped from the familiar darkness of his home into the unknown darkness of the Age of Ice. He emerged from the hillside, setting foot on grass. Not snow, and the night air was crisp but lacked the biting chill he had been warned of all his life. He stretched out his arms, marveling at the open space all around, and broke into a run down the hillside. Running was foolhardy in the Underhome. Low ceilings, sharp turns, and sudden drops presented challenges that demanded a careful step, but here there was freedom.[PARAGRAPH:1]And danger. Kandros found himself surrounded by large, grey dogs. He realized he had nearly charged into the den of these animals, and they cared little for his reason for being there. His hand axe was out barely before the first leapt for his throat. It was his blade that found the wolves throat first. And the skull of the next wolf to charge him. He became a whirl of axe and torch until the last beast lay dead or dying.[PARAGRAPH:1]So many animals... how could there be prey enough for a pack of this size in the wasteland he had been lead to believe the surface was? Then he noticed something half buried in the wolves' den. He walked over slowly, pulling the body from the debris, his breath held tight. Unmistakably the body of a dwarf, though it was a gruesome sight to see after the wolves had fed on its flesh. The pattern of the clothing marked it as a clansman of his, and Kandros knew he had found his cousin. He rent his beard and wept over the body. After a time he gathered the gathered up the body, intending to bury it within sight of the Underhome. Then he noticed ... the left shoulder blade was shorn in two. Not broken, but split with a clean cut. He examined it carefully. Luach had been hit from behind by a battle axe, almost certainly by someone of his height.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Murder..." he whispered to the night.[PARAGRAPH:1]He was answered, not by the night, but by a cloaked dwarf holding a Mithril axe directly behind him. "He, like you, wouldn't leave well enough alone, Fir." The dwarf swung his axe for the kill, but then dropped it clumsily and gurgled blood.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Kandros!" Arturus shouted from the entrance of the wolf den, his axe embedded in the neck of the cloaked dwarf. The two friends embraced.[PARAGRAPH:1]"I found Luach, and his killer I think," Kandros informed his friend.[PARAGRAPH:1]Arturus Thorne went pale. "And I found my cousin as well." The dwarf he had killed was the prince Grunnos.[PARAGRAPH:2]The last time Kandros had been in the King's Hall, he had petitioned for permission to search out his cousin. Now, it was with accusation that the King's own son had killed his kin. Were it not for the well respected Arturus beside him, he would have been called a murderer, and worse, a name-killer for making accusations against Grunnos. Kanlore stood from his throne and faced the two Dwarves, his beard reaching nearly his full height. His eldest son and his honor guard flanked him; otherwise the chamber was empty. "You defied the laws of your people, Kandros Fir. The surface world is a harsh land ruled by a dread god and his legion of giants. It was treason to leave."[PARAGRAPH:1]Kandros did not interrupt his king, but rebuked him when he had finished. "The ice is long gone, my liege, and Winter has passed. Your laws made my people's home a prison, and it was based on lies!"[PARAGRAPH:1]"Tis true, uncle," spoke Arturus. "Your scouts have surely misled you for years!"[PARAGRAPH:1]"Not years, foolish Arturus. The ravages of Winter were real enough 10 months ago."[PARAGRAPH:1]"You knew?" gasped Kandros.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Yes, but your cousin had to die to keep this secret. Even with the Winter King gone, the surface world is a vicious realm. Elves and humans wield magic that can destroy any warrior. Greed makes warfare or subjugation unending. Here my people are safe, and here they shall remain."[PARAGRAPH:1]"We are not your children, to be locked away for our own protection. Let the Khazad go forth and prove our worth, not cower in stone chambers like men already dead! You have stolen our spirit, and I name you coward, Kanlore, be it treason or no!"[PARAGRAPH:1]"Enough! Guards, kill them!" The honor guard readied their axes, but looked around, uncertain.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Are you insane, father? These men did no wrong. You did, and you shamed yourself and your kin." Prince Toril sliced off his braided beard and threw it in the king's face. "You shall have no allegiance when word of this perfidy reaches beyond this hall. Nor shall any of your line." The guards heeded his words, and lowered their weapons.[PARAGRAPH:1]"So you too turn. My son, hear this-when the last dwarf is hunted down, felled by lance or wand, be it your name that they curse with their last breath!" Kanlore staggered from the royal hall, towards the surface that he so feared and into exile.[PARAGRAPH:1]The prince turned to Arturus. "Cousin, you are my closest living kin not of my father. It is you the people shall follow."[PARAGRAPH:1]Arturus turned to his old friend. "Kandros, could you not have left this alone as I so asked? Because of you I have become kin-slayer and usurper."[PARAGRAPH:1]"What? This foul scene was Kanlore's doing!"[PARAGRAPH:1]"What I say now I say with heavy heart but the weight of the crown. You sought the surface world, and there you must go, banished from the Underhome. Take provisions, take your clan, take all who would seek their fortune above. This is not justice, but there will not be order in the Underhome while a traitor walks its halls, and you did break the royal decree when you left." Arturus sighed. "As did I, when I followed you. Toril, if you will not be king, then be my viceroy, and I shall take the crown to the surface as punishment for my own disobedience, with whoever will follow me."[PARAGRAPH:1]And so the King of the Dwarves left the Underhome for the first time in over 300 years, and at the same time the Fir clan and their allies parted with their allies to forge their own Khazad nation. The two men who had been closest of fiends grew to be the fiercest of rivals for much of the last Age.
TEXT.French: Arturus trouva son ami à la lueur de la bougie. Les torches étaient interdites dans cette chambre sainte, loin dans les entrailles de Maisonterre. La suie et la fumée qu'elles produisent obscurcissaient les runes gravées dans les rangées de piliers, recouvrant les noms et les faits des ancêtres nains honorés. Les anciens nains qui gardaient ces sites, gravant de nouvelles histoires et apprenant aux autres à les lire étaient appelés officiellement les Gardiens des Runes, mais en général surnommés les 'Mains des Prophéties'. Louchant à la lumière des bougies qui leur dérobait si souvent la vue, ils avaient appris à lire chaque mot et lettre avec les mains. Kandros Fir etait à la fin de la section de son Clan dans la Salle des Runes, un ciseau à la main.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Je savais que je te trouverais là," dit Arturus tout en s'agenouillant à ses côtés.[PARAGRAPH:1]"J'étais son parent le plus proche. Je dois ajouter son nom et ses actes à notre histoire."[PARAGRAPH:1]"Bien sûr, mon vieil ami. Mais ce n'est pas la seule chose que tu comptes faire, n'est ce pas ?" Kandros baissa la tête.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Je suis fidèle à mon roi, par mes os, je suis loyal."[PARAGRAPH:1]"Mais ?"[PARAGRAPH:1]"Je ne peux pas plus abandonner ma famille que choir sous ma propre hache ! Imagine si ton couson Grunnos était porté disparu. Que ferais-tu ?"[PARAGRAPH:1]Arturus grogna. "Ne parle pas de ce prodigue, mais estime toi heureux qu'il ait de nombreux frères ainés prétendants au trone avant lui si notre bon Kanlore devait mourir."[PARAGRAPH:1]"Mais ?"[PARAGRAPH:1]"Mais si son destin devait être le même que Luach, je creuserais jusqu'à l'enfer de Mammon pour le retrouver. Mais pas si mon roi me l'interdit ! Je connais les liens de parenté, mais qu'en est-il des amis ? Abandonnes-tu ton devoir et tes amis pour une folle quête ? L'hiver te prendra aussi, et qu'auras-tu alors prouvé ?"[PARAGRAPH:1]Kandros se leva, remettant le marteau et le ciseau sur l'autel tandis qu'il partait. "Mon devoir a d'autres pour s'en occuper, de même que mes amis, cher Arturus. Mais Luach Fir est seul. Si notre amitié a un sens pour toi, tu ne me gêneras pas."[PARAGRAPH:2]Ça n'avait pas été simple de parvenir à la surface. Personne n'avait été autorisé à partir depuis que Luach, le cousin de Kandros, était parti pour étudier la surface. L'hiver faisait encore rage, comme il le faisait depuis plus de six générations, mais le jeune Luach n'avait pas froid aux yeux et avait harcelé Kanlore pour pouvoir partir et explorer la rude surface qu'importe le danger. Le ravitaillement était chose rare à Maisonterre. Leurs stocks de poudre noire avait été épuisés depuis si longtemps que les derniers nains qui auraient pu ne serait-ce que l'identifier étaient morts, et l'expansion de Maisonterre était fastidieuse à l'aide de pioches et de marteaux. Les épices s'étaient épuisées dans la jeunesse de Kandros, et le porc et les tubercules restants pour nourrir ses enfants faisaient des repas une corvée. Ainsi Luach avait été autorisé à faire une nouvelle éaluation de l'état de la froide surface, mais les craintes de Kanlore s'étaient avérées lorsque Luach n'était pas revenu pendant des mois. Aujourd'hui, plus personne n'était autorisé à partir, impliquant que Kandros devrait se faufiler au travers des gardes dans le noir, et serait méprisé s'il revenait jamais.[PARAGRAPH:1]La sortie de la maison Naine était scellée par un porte massive en pierre, et Kandros s'épuisa en tentant de l'ouvrir, utilisant même sa pioche comme levier. Il passa bravement des ténèbres familières de sa maison aux ténèbres inconnues de l'Âge de Glace. Il émergea sur la pente de la colline, posant le pied sur l'herbe. Pas de neige, et l'air nocturne était froid mais ne possédait par ce froid mordant dont il avait été mis en garde toute sa vie. Il étira ses bras, s'émerveillant de l'espace libre tout autour, et se lança dans une course vers le bas de la colline. Courir était téméraire à Maisonterre. Plafonds bas, virages serrés, et gouffres soudains représentaient des défis qui requiéraient un pas prudent, mais ici se trouvait la liberté.[PARAGRAPH:1]Et le danger. Kandros se retrouva encerclé par de grands chiens gris. Il se rendit compte qu'il s'était précipité dans la tanière de ces animaux, et qu'ils se fichaient des raisons de sa présence. Sa hache sortit à peine avant que le premier lui saute à la gorge. Ce fut sa lame qui rencontra la première la gorge du loup. Et le crâne du second à le charger. Il devint une tornade de hache et continua jusqu'à ce que la dernière bête gît morte ou mourante.[PARAGRAPH:1]Tant d'animaux... Comment pouvait-il y avoir assez de proies pour une meute de cette taille dans les terres désolées que lui avaient été présentées la surface ? Puis il remarqua quelque chose à moitié enterré dans la tanière des loups. Il le surplomba puis dégagea doucement le corps des débris, retenant son souffle. Sans soute possible le corps d'un nain, bien que ce fût une vision hideuse après ce que les loups avaient fait à sa chair. Les vêtements l'identifiaient comme un membre de son clan, et Kandros sut qu'il avait retrouvé son cousin. Il caressa sa barbe et pleura sur le corps. Au bout d'un moment, il rassembla les parties du corps, comptant l'enterrer en vue de Maisonterre. Puis il remarqua... l'épaule gauche était coupée en deux. Pas brisée, mais coupée nette. Il l'eximina avec attention. Luach avait été touché dans le dos par une hache de bataille, certainement par une personne de sa taille.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Meurtre..." chuchota-t-il dans la nuit.[PARAGRAPH:1]Il eut une réponse, non pas par la nuit, mais par un nain encapuchonné tenant une hache en Mithril juste derrière lui. "Comme toi, seul, il ne vivait pas assez bien, Fir." Le nain abattit sa hache pour tuer, mais la lâcha maladroitement et se mit à gragouiller du sang.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Kandros !" cria Arturus depuis l'entrée de la tanière des nains, sa hache enfoncée dans la nuque du nain encapuchonné. Les deux amis s'étreignirent.[PARAGRAPH:1]"J'ai trouvé Luach, ainsi que son meurtrier je pense," dit Kandros à son ami.[PARAGRAPH:1]Arturus Thorne devint pâle. "Et j'ai également trouvé mon cousin." Le nain qu'il avait tué et le prince Grunnos.[PARAGRAPH:2]La dernière fois que Kandros avait été dans le Hall Royal, il demandait la permission d'aller chercher son cousin. Aujourd'hui, c'était avec l'accusation que le propre fils du Roi avait tué sa famille. S'il n'y avait pas eu le respecté Arturus pour le soutenir, il aurait été appelé meurtrier, et pire, un tueur-de-nom pour ses accusations envers Grunnos. Kanlore se leva de son trône et fit face aux deux nains, sa barbe touchant presque le sol. Son fils aîné et ses thanes le flanquaient ; sinon la chambre était vide. "Tu as défié les lois de ton peuple, Kandros Fir. Le monde de la surface est une terre inhospitalière dirigée par un dieu redoutable et ses légions de géants. C'était une trahison que de partir.'[PARAGRAPH:1]Kandros n'interrompit pas son roi, mais le contredit quand il eut fini. "La glace a disparu depuis longtemps, mon seigneur, et l'Hiver s'est terminé. Vos lois ont fait de la maison de mon peuple une prison, et basé sur des mensonges !"[PARAGRAPH:1]"C'vrai, mon oncle," acquiesca Arturus. "Vos éclaireurs vous ont sûrement trompés pendant des années !"[PARAGRAPH:1]"Pas des années, mon pauvre Arturus. Les ravages de l'Hiver étaient encore bien présents il y a 10 mois."[PARAGRAPH:1]"Vous saviez ?" s'étrangla Kandros.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Oui, mais ton cousin devait mourir pour garder ça secret. Même avec le Roi de l'Hiver disparu, le monde de la surface est un royaume vicieux. Elfes et humains sont porteurs de magie qui peuvent détruire n'importe quel guerrier. L'avidité rend la guerre et les soumissions sans fin. Ici mon peuple est en sécurité, et ici ils doivent rester."[PARAGRAPH:1]"Nous ne sommes pas vos enfants, devant être enfermés pour notre propre protection. Laissez les khazadors aller de l'avant et prouver notre valeur, et non pas se terrer dans des chambres de pierre comme des hommes déjà morts ! Vous nous avez volé notre âme, et je vous accuse de couardise, Kanlore, que ce soit de la trahison ou non !"[PARAGRAPH:1]"Assez ! Guardes, tuez-les !" Les thanes préparèrent leurs haches, mais regardèrent autour d'eux, incertains.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Etes-vous devenu fou, mon père ? Ces hommes n'ont rien fait de mal. Vous en avez fait, et vous vous êtes couvert de honte, vous et voter famille." Le prince Toril se sectionna sa barbe tressée et la jeta au visage du toi. "Vous n'aurez plus aucune allégeance quand ces mots si perfides sortiront de ces murs. Ni personne de votre lignée." Les thanes acquiescèrent et baissèrent leurs armes.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Et maintenant c'est toi qui me tourne le dos. Mon fils, écoute moi : quand le dernier nain sera abattu, transpercé par une lance ou une flèche, que ce soit ton nom qu'ils maudiront dans leur dernier souffle !" Kanlore tituba depuis le Hall Royal vers la surface tant redoutée et vers son exil.[PARAGRAPH:1]Le prince se tourna vers Arturus. "Cousin, tu es ma famille vivante la plus proche qui ne soi pas de mon père. C'est quoi que le peuple doit suivre."[PARAGRAPH:1]Arturus se tourna vers son vieil ami. "Kandros, tu n'aurais pas pu laisser tomber comme je te l'avais demandé ? À cause de toi je suis devenu un régicide et un usurpateur."[PARAGRAPH:1]"Quoi ? Cet épisode méprisable était l'œuvre de Kanlore !"[PARAGRAPH:1]"Ce que je dis maintenant, je le dis le cœur lourd mais avec le poids de la couronne. Tu courais après le monde de la surface, alors tu iras, banni de Maisonterre. Prends des provisions, emmène ton clan, emmène tous ceux qui souhaitent trouver fortune là-haut. Ce n'est pas la justice, mais il ne pourra pas y avoir d'ordre à Maisonterre tant qu'un traitre parcourra ses couloirs, et tu as brisé le traité royal quand tu es parti." Arturus soupira. "Tout comme moi, quand je t'ai suivi. Toril, si tu ne veux pas être roi, alors soit mon viceroi, et j'emmènerai la couronne à la surface comme cha^timent pour ma propre désobéissance, avec quiconque voudra me suivre."[PARAGRAPH:1]Ainsi le Roi des Nains quitta Maisonterre pour la première fois depuis 300 ans, tandis que le clan Fir et leurs alliés s'en allaient forger leur propre nation Khazadore. Les deux hommes qui avaient été les plus proches amis devirent les pires rivaux du dernier Âge.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Arturus fand seinen Freund im Kerzenlicht. Fackeln waren verboten in dieser heiligen Kammer, tief in der Unterwelt. Der Ruß und Rauch, den sie abgaben, bedeckte die in die Reihen von Säulen eingemeißelten Runen, die von den Namen und Taten der ehrwürdigen Vorfahren der Zwerge handelten. Die alten Zwerge, die diese Stätte hüteten, dort neue Geschichten eingravierten und andere lehrten, sie zu lesen, wurden offiziell 'Runenwächter' genannt. Geläufiger war jedoch 'Handseher'. Das stete Spähen durch den Kerzenschein raubte ihnen ihr Augenlicht, also erlernten sie jedes Wort und jeden Buchstaben nur mit Hilfe ihrer Finger zu lesen. Kandros Fir war am Ende des Abschnitts seines Clans in der Runenhalle, den Meißel noch in der Hand.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Ich wusste, ich würde Euch hier finden", sagte Arturus, während er sich neben ihn kniete.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Ich bin sein nächster Verwandter. Ich muss seinen Namen und seine Taten unserer Geschichte hinzufügen."[PARAGRAPH:1]"Natürlich, alter Freund. Aber das ist nicht dein ganzer Plan, oder irre ich mich?" Kandros neigte seinen Kopf.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Ich bin dem König treu, bei meinen Gebeinen, ich bin loyal."[PARAGRAPH:1]"Aber?"[PARAGRAPH:1]"Ich falle eher in meine eigene Axt, als meine Familie aufzugeben! Wenn Euer Vetter Grunnos vermisst werden würde. Was würdet Ihr tun?"[PARAGRAPH:1]Arturus schnaubte. "Sprecht nicht von diesem Verschwender, sondern seid glücklich, dass er viele ältere Brüder hat, die vor ihm König werden, sollte der gute Kanlore dahinscheiden.."[PARAGRAPH:1]"Aber?"[PARAGRAPH:1]"Aber ... wäre sein Schicksal das von Luach, sollte ich mich bis in Mammons Hölle graben, damit es ihm zuteil wird. Aber nicht, wenn mein König es verbietet! Ich kenne die Fesseln der Blutsverwandtschaft, aber was ist mit Euren Kindern? Gebt Ihr Eure Pflichten und Freunde für eine verrückte Suche auf? Der Winter wird auch Euch holen, und wofür?"[PARAGRAPH:1]Kandros erhob sich, legte Hammer und Meißel zurück auf den Altar, um sich Richtung Ausgang zu wenden. "Meinen Pflichten können sich andere widmen, und meinen Freunden ebenso, lieber Arturus. Aber Luach Fir ist allein. Wenn Euch unsere Freundschaft etwas bedeutet, werdet Ihr mich nicht hindern."[PARAGRAPH:2]Es war nicht einfach zur Oberfläche zu gelangen. Niemandem war es erlaubt, seit Kandros' Vetter Luach aufbrach um die Oberfläche zu studieren. Der Winter wütete immer noch, wie er es seit sechs Generationen getan hatte, aber der junge Luach war unverdrossen und hatte Kanlore ersucht, gehen zu dürfen um die unwirsche Oberfläche zu erforschen ohne Rücksicht auf die Gefahren. Die Vorräte waren mager in der Unterwelt. Ihre Schwarzpulver-Lager waren schon so lange erschöpft, dass die letzten Zwerge, die sie überhaupt erkennen könnten dahingeschieden sind, und der Ausbau der Unterwelt war mühsam mit Pickel und Hammer. Gewürze gingen schon früh in Kandros' Jugend aus, und das Schweinefleisch und die Wurzelknollen, mit denen seine Kinder ernährt wurden, machten aus der Ernährung eine lästige Pflicht. Also wurde Luach letztendlich gewährt, eine weitere Einschätzung des Zustands der Oberfläche vorzunehmen, doch stellte sich Kanlores Unsicherheit als berechtigt heraus, da Luach seit Monaten nicht zurückgekehrt war. Niemandem war es nun erlaubt zu gehen, was bedeutete, dass Kandros sich im Dunkeln an Wachen vorbeischleichen musste und in Verruf geriet, sollte er zurückkehren. [PARAGRAPH:1]Der Ausgang der Zwergenheimat war durch eine massive Steintür versiegelt und Kandros verausgabte sich vollkommen dabei, sie mit seiner Spitzhacke als Hebel aufzustemmen. Tapfer schritt er aus der vertrauten Dunkelheit seiner Heimat in die unbekannte Dunkelheit der Eiszeit. Er kam an einem Abhang zum Vorschein, die Füße im Gras. Kein Schnee. Die Nachtluft war frostig, aber vermisste die beißende Kälte, vor der er sein gesamtes Leben lang gewarnt wurde. Er streckte die Arme aus, staunte über den freien Raum, der ihn umgab, und sprintete den Abhang hinunter. Rennen war töricht in der Unterwelt. Niedrige Decken, scharfe Kurven und plötzliche Senken waren Herausforderungen, die einen vorsichtigen Gang verlangten. Aber hier war Freiheit.[PARAGRAPH:1]Und Gefahr. Kandros fand sich umzingelt von großen, grauen Wölfen wieder. Er erkannte, dass er fast direkt in den Bau dieser Tiere gestürmt wäre und sie kümmert sich wenig um seine Motive. Kaum bevor ihm der erste an die Kehle sprang hatte er seine Handaxt hervor geholt. Doch seine Klinge fand die Kehle des Wolfes zuerst. Und den Schädel des nächsten Wolfes, der ihn angriff. Er wurde zu einem Wirbel aus Axt und Fackel bis die letzte Bestie tot oder sterbend am Boden lag...[PARAGRAPH:1]So viele Tiere... wie konnte es genug Beute für ein Rudel dieser Größe in der Einöde geben, die die Oberfläche angeblich sein sollte? Dann entdeckte er etwas, halb vergraben im der Wolfsbau. Er schlich langsam hin, zog den Körper aus dem Geröll und hielt den Atem an. Unverkennbar die Leiche eines Zwergs, auch wenn es ein grausamer Anblick war, nachdem sich die Wölfe an dem Fleisch satt gefressen hatten. Das Muster der Kleidung verriet den Toten als ein Mitglied seines Clans und Kandros war klar, dass er seinen Vetter gefunden hatte. Er zerriss sich den Bart und weinte über dem leblosen Körper. Nach einiger Zeit sammelte er die Leiche in der Absicht auf, sie in Sichtweite zum Eingang zur Zwergenwelt zu begraben. Dann bemerkte er es ... das linke Schulterblatt war entzwei getrennt. Nicht gebrochen, sondern getrennt mit einem sauberen Schnitt. Er untersuchte es vorsichtig. Luach wurde von hinten von einer Kriegsaxt getroffen, nahezu sicher von jemandem seiner Größe.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Mord ..." flüsterte er in die Nacht.[PARAGRAPH:1]Er bekam keine Antwort von der Nacht, aber von einem verhüllten Zwerg mit einer Mithrilaxt direkt hinter ihm. "Er würde es, genau wie ihr, einfach nicht gut sein lassen, Fir!" Der Zwerg schwang seine Axt zum Töten, doch ließ sie plump fallen und gurgelte Blut...[PARAGRAPH:1]"Kandros!" rief Arturus vom Eingang der Wolfshöhle, die Axt noch im Nacken des verhüllten Zwerges steckend. Die zwei Freunde umarmten sich.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Ich habe Luach gefunden, und seinen Mörder ebenfalls denke ich," informierte Kandros seinen Freund.[PARAGRAPH:1]Arturus Thorne wurde blass. "Und ich habe meinen Vetter auch gefunden." Der Zwerg, den er tötete, war Prinz Grunnos.[PARAGRAPH:2]Das letzte Mal als Kandros im Königssaal war bat er um Erlaubnis nach seinem Vetter zu suchen. Diesmal mit der Anschuldigung, dass des Königs eigener Sohn seinen Verwandten ermordet hatte. Wäre nicht der hoch angesehene Arturus an seiner Seite, wäre er als Mörder beschuldigt worden und, noch schlimmer, als Verleumder aufgrund der Anklage gegen Grunnos. Kanlore stand vor seinem Thron den zwei Zwergen gegenüber, den Bart fast bis zum Boden. Sein ältester Sohn und seine Ehrenwache flankierten ihn; ansonsten war der Raum leer. "Du hast dich den Gesetzen deines Volkes widersetzt, Kandros Fir. Die Welt an der Oberfläche ist eine brutales Land regiert von einem Gott des Schreckens und seine Legion von Riesen. Zu gehen war Hochverrat!"[PARAGRAPH:1]Kandros unterbrach seinen König nicht, sondern wies ihn zurecht nachdem er fertig war. "Das Eis ist lange fort, mein Lehnsheer, und der Winter ist vorbei. Eure Gesetze machten die Heimat meines Volkes zu einem Gefängnis, und alles beruht auf einer Lüge!"[PARAGRAPH:1]"Es ist wahr, Onkel", sprach Arturus. "Eure Kundschafter haben euch jahrelang getäuscht!"[PARAGRAPH:1]"Nicht Jahre, dummer Arturus. Das verheerende Wüten des Winters war vor zehn Monaten noch real."[PARAGRAPH:1]"Ihr wusstet davon?" stieß Kandros hervor.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Ja, und dein Vetter musste sterben um dieses Geheimnis zu bewahren. Selbst wenn der Winterkönig abgetreten ist, ist die Oberfläche ein boshaftes Reich. Elfen und Menschen üben Magie aus, die jeden Krieger zerstören kann. Raffgier macht Krieg und Unterwerfung endlos. Hier ist mein Volk sicher, und hier sollen sie bleiben."[PARAGRAPH:1]"Wir sind nicht Eure Kinder, die weggesperrt werden müssen zu ihrer eigenen Sicherheit. Lasst die Khazad vorwärts und beweist unseren Wert, und hockt nicht in Steinkammern wie die Toten! Ihr habt unsere Seele gestohlen, und ich nenne Euch einen Feigling, Kanlore, sei es Verrat oder nicht!"[PARAGRAPH:1]"Genug! Wachen, tötet sie!" Die Ehrenwache machte ihre Äxte bereit aber sah sich unsicher um.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Seid Ihr wahnsinnig, Vater? Diese Männer haben nichts Falsches getan. Ihr schon und Ihr beschämt euch selbst und eure Sippe." Prinz Toril schnitt seinen geflochtenen Bart ab und warf ihn dem König ins Gesicht. "Ihr sollt keine Treue erwarten, wenn das Wort dieser Niedertracht diese Halle verlässt. Ihr und niemand Eurer Linie." Die Wachen beherzigten seine Worte und senkten ihre Waffen.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Ihr also auch... mein Sohn, höre mir zu, wenn die letzten Zwerge gejagt wurden, von einem Speer oder Zauberstab getötet, dann sei es dein Name, den sie mit ihrem letzten Atemzug verfluchen!" Kanlore schwankte aus der königlichen Halle in Richtung Oberfläche, die er so fürchtete, ins Exil.[PARAGRAPH:1]Der Prinz wand sich Arturus zu. "Vetter, Ihr seid mein nächster Verwandter, abgesehen von meinem Vater. Ihr seid es, dem das Volk folgen sollte."[PARAGRAPH:1]Arturus drehte sich zu seinem alten Freund. "Kandros, hättet ihr das ganze nicht unbehelligt lassen können, wie ich Euch gebeten habe? Wegen euch bin ich ein Blutsmörder und Usurpator geworden."[PARAGRAPH:1]"Was? Dieser schändliche Vorfall war Kanlores Tat!"[PARAGRAPH:1]"Was ich nun sage, sage ich schweren Herzens, doch unter der Last der Krone. Ihr suchtet nach der Oberfläche und dort müsst ihr hingehen, verbannt aus der Unterwelt. Nehmt Vorräte, nehmt Euren Clan, nehmt alle, die ihre Zukunft dort oben sehen. Dies ist nicht gerecht, aber es wird keine Ordnung in der Unterwelt geben solange ein Verräter in diesen Hallen wandelt, und Ihr braucht das königliche Dekret um zu gehen." Arturus seufzte. "Genau wie ich, als ich Euch folgte. Toril, wenn Ihr nicht auf den Thron wollt, dann seid mein Vizekönig und ich trage die Krone zur Oberfläche als Strafe für meinen eigenen Ungehorsam, wer auch immer mir folgt."[PARAGRAPH:1]Und so verließ der König der Zwerge die Unterwelt das erste Mal nach 300 Jahren und zugleich ging auch der Fir-Clan und seine Verbündeten um ihre eigene Khazad-Nation zu schmieden. Die beiden Männer, die beste Freunde waren, wurden zu den erbittertsten Rivalen für den Großteil des letzten Zeitalters.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]Arturus trovò il suo amico con la luce della candela. Le torcie erano proibite in queste sacre stanze, nelle profondità del Sottosuolo. La fuliggine e il fumo che generavano avrebbero oscurato le rune incise sulle colonne li presenti, coprendo i nomi e le gesta degli onorati antenati dei Nani. Gli antichi nani che si prendevano cura di questi luoghi, che incidevano nuove storie e inesgnavano agli altri a leggerle, erano chiamati Custodi delle Rune ufficialmente ma venivano chiamati più comunemente 'Veggenti delle Mani'. Il lavorare sempre alla tenue luce delle candele li aveva invariabilmente danneggiato la vista, per questo avevano imparato ogni parola e lettera col tatto. Kandros Fir era alla fine della sezione del suo Clan nella Sala delle Rune con lo scalpello in mano.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Sapevo che ti avrei trovato qui," Arturus disse inginocchiandosi vicino a lui.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Ero il suo parente più stretto. Devo aggiungere il suo nome e le sue gesta alla nostra storia."[PARAGRAPH:1]"Ovviamente, vecchio amico. Ma non è l'unica cosa che stai pianificando, nevvero?" Kandros chinò la testa.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Sono fedele al nostro re, fin nelle ossa, sono fedele."[PARAGRAPH:1]"Ma?"[PARAGRAPH:1]"Non posso abbandonare la mia famiglia nello stesso modo in cui non posso cadere sulla mia ascia! Immagina se tuo cugino Grunnos fosse disperso. Che cosa faresti?"[PARAGRAPH:1]Arturus sbuffò. "Non parlarmi di quel buono a nulla, ma sii contento che ha molti fratelli più grandi che diventeranno re prima di lui nel caso il buon Kanlore ci lasciasse."[PARAGRAPH:1]"Ma?"[PARAGRAPH:1]"Ma... se avesse avuto lo stesso destino di Luach, scaverei sino all'inferno di Mammon se farlo mi permetterebbe di ritrovarlo. Ma non se il mio re me lo proibisce! Comprendo i legami di famiglia, ma che dire di kith? Abbandoni il tuo dovere e i tuoi amici per una folle ricerca? L'inverno prenderebbe pure te, e cosa avrai ottenuto?"[PARAGRAPH:1]Kandros si alzò, ripose il martello e lo scalpello sull'altare e si voltò per andarsene. "Il mio dovere ha altri che se ne possono occupare, e i miei amici ugualmente, caro Arturus. Ma Luach Fir è da solo. Se la nostra amicizia ha un qualche valore per te, non mi ostacolerai."[PARAGRAPH:2]Non era stato facile raggiungere la superfice. A nessuno era permesso uscire da quando il cugino di Kandros, Luach, era andato a studiare la superfice. L'inverno continuava a imperversare nello stesso modo che aveva fatto per altre sei generazioni, ma il giovane Luach era imperterrito, e aveva chesto a Kanlore di poter uscire per esplorare l'aspra superficie non curante del pericolo. Le provviste erano scarse nel Sottosuolo. Le loro scorte di polvere nera si erano esaurite cosi tanto tempo fa che gli ultimi nani che avrebbero potuto riconoscerla erano morti, e l'espansione del Sottosuolo era ora un lavoro tedioso di piccone e martello. Le spezie erano finite durante l'infanzia di Kandros, e il maiale e le patate che i suoi figli mangiavano non rendeva il mangiare esattamente invitante. Quindi alla fine Luach ottenne il permesso per andare a fare una stima della desolata superficie, ma l'esitazione di Kanlore nel dare il permesso si dimostrò sensata quando Luach non tornò per mesi. Nessuno poteva uscire ora, il che significava che Kandros avrebbe dovuto superare di nascosto le guardie al buio, e che sarebbe stato malvisto se avesse mai fatto ritorno.[PARAGRAPH:1]L'uscita era bloccata da una massiccia porta di pietra, e Kandros si sfinì nell'aprirla, perfino usando il suo piccone come leva. Passò coraggiosamente dall'oscurità familiare della sua casa a quella sconosciuta dell'Era del Ghiaccio. Uscì sul lato di una collina, calpensando dell'erba. Niente neve, e l'aria della notte era frizzante, ma gli mancava il freddo pungente da cui era stato messo in guardia per tutta la vita. Estese le braccia, meravigliandosi di tutto lo spazio aperto intorno a lui e si mise a correre giù dalla collina. Correre era imprudente nel Sottosuolo. Soffitti bassi, curve strette, e baratri improvvisi richiedevano un passo attento, ma qui c'era la libertà.[PARAGRAPH:1]E il pericolo. Kandros scoprì di essere circondato da dei grossi cani grigi. Capì che era quasi entrato di corsa nella tana di questi animali, e poco importava loro quali erano le ragioni della sua presenza. La sua ascia era appena uscita dal fodero quando il primo provò a saltargli addosso. Fu la sua lama a colpire per prima. Per poi colpire il teschio del secondo lupo che gli si era avvicinato. Divenne un turbine di ascia e torcia fino a quando l'ultima delle bestie non era morta o morente.[PARAGRAPH:1]Cosi tanti animali... come potevano esserci prede sufficenti per un branco di tale grandezza nelle terre desolate che era stato portato a credere fosse la superficie? Poi notò qualcosa mezzo sepolta nella tana dei lupi. Gli si avvicinò lentamente, estraendola dai detriti col fiato sospeso. Inconfondibilmente il corpo di un nano, benché non fosse una bella vista dopo che i lupi si erano cibati della carne. Lo stile dei vestiti lo identificava come un membro del suo clan, e Kandros capì che aveva trovato suo cugino. Si strappò la barba e pianse sul corpo. Dopo un pò raccolse i resti del corpo, con l'intenzione di seppellirlo in vista del Sottosuolo. Poi notò una cosa... la scapola sinistra era tagliata in due. Non rotta, ma con un taglio netto. La esaminò accuratamente. Luach era stato colpito da dietro con un'ascia da battaglia, quasi sicuramente da uno della sua altezza.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Un omicidio..." sussurrò alla notte.[PARAGRAPH:1]Ottenne risposta, non dalla notte, ma da un nano ammantato che impugnava un'ascia in Mithril dietro di lui. "Lui, come te, non è andato lontano da solo, Fir". Il nano iniziò a vibrare il colpo per poi cadere a terra goffamente e sputare sangue.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Kandros!" Arturus urlò dall'entrata della tana dei lupi con la sua ascia incastrata nel collo del nano ammantato. I due amici si abbracciarono.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Ho trovato Luach, e il suo assassino credo" Kandros disse all'amico.[PARAGRAPH:1]Arturus Thorne impallidì. "E io ho trovato il mio di cugino". Il nano che aveva ucciso era il principe Grunnos.[PARAGRAPH:2]L'ultima volta che Kandros era stato nella Sala del Re era per chiedere il permesso di andare a cercare il cugino. Adesso vi era per accusare il figlio del Re di aver ucciso dei familiari. Se non fosse stato per il tanto rispettato Arturus al suo fianco sarebbe stato etichettato come un omicida e, ancora peggio, un uccisore di nomi per aver formulato delle accuse contro Grunnos. Kanlore si alzò dal trono e andò davanti ai due nani, la sua barba era lunga quasi quanto lui. Il figlio più grande e la sua guardia d'onore gli stavano a fianco; oltre loro non vi era nessuno. "Hai disubbidito alle leggi del tuo popolo, Kandros Fir. Il mondo della superficie è una terra crudele governata da un temibile dio e dalla sua legione di giganti. Andarsene è stato un atto di tradimento".[PARAGRAPH:1]Kandros non interruppe il suo re, ma lo criticò una volta che aveva finito. "Il ghiaccio è sparito da tempo, mio signore, e l'Inverno è passato. Le vostre leggi hanno reso la casa del mio popolo una prigione, ed erano tutte basate su bugie!"[PARAGRAPH:1]"È vero zio" disse Arturus. "I tuoi ricoglitori ti hanno sicuramente ingannato per anni!"[PARAGRAPH:1]"Non anni, stolto Arturus. La desolazione dell'Inverno era abbastanza reale 10 mesi fa".[PARAGRAPH:1]"Lo sapevi?" disse Kandros.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Si, ma tuo cugino doveva morire per mantenere il segreto. Anche senza il Re dell'Inverno il mondo in superficie è un luogo pericoloso. Elfi ed umani utilizzano magie che possono distruggere qualsiasi guerriero. L'avidità rende la guerra o l'oppressione senza fine. Qui il mio popolo è al sicuro, e qui rimarrà".[PARAGRAPH:1]"Noi non siamo i tuoi figli, che puoi rinchiuderci da qualche parte per la nostra salvaguardia. Lascia che i Khazad progrediscano e dimostrino il loro valore, non nascondendoli in stanze di pietra come fosserò già morti! Ci hai privato del nostro spirito e ti chaimo codardo, Kanlore, si tratti di tradimento o no!"[PARAGRAPH:1]"Basta! Guardie, uccideteli!" Le guardie d'onore impugnarono le loro asce, ma si guardavano intorno, incerte.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Siete impazzito, padre? Non hanno fatto nulla di sbagliato. Tu lo hai fatto, e hai disonorato te e la tua stirpe." Il principe Toril si tagliò la barba intrecciata e la lanciò in faccia al re. "Nessuno ti sarà fedele quando le voci della tua perfidia usciranno da questa stanza. Come pure la tua stirpe". Le guardie ascoltarono le sue parole ed abbassarono le armi.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Quindi anche tu schieri contro di me. Figlio mio ascolta bene, quando l'ultimo nano verrà abbattuto, da una lancia o una bacchetta, sarà il tuo nome ad essere maledetto col loro ultimo respiro!" Kanlore barcollò fuori dalla sala regale e verso la superficie che tanto temeva in esilio.[PARAGRAPH:1]Il pincipe si rivolse ad Arturus. "Cugino, tu sei il mio familiare più prossimo che non discende da mio padre. Sei tu colui che il nostro popolo seguirà."[PARAGRAPH:1]Arturus si voltò verso il suo vecchio amico. "Kandros, non potevi lasciare le cose come stavano come ti avevo chiesto? A causa tua sono diventato un uccisore di parenti e un'usurpatore."[PARAGRAPH:1]"Cosa? Questa situazione è opera di Kanlore!"[PARAGRAPH:1]"Quello che sto per dire lo dico col cuore pesante e il peso della corona. Hai cercato il mondo di superficie, e li devi andare, bandito dal Sottosuolo. Prendi provviste, prendi il tuo clan, prendi tutti quelli che vogliono cercar fortuna li sopra. Questa non è giustizia, ma non vi sarà ordine nel Sottosuolo fin quando un traditore cammina nelle sue sale, e tu hai infranto il decreto reale quando sei uscito." Arturus sospirò. "Come ho fatto io quando ti ho seguito. Toril, se non sarai il mio re, allora sii il mio viceré, e io porterò la mia corona in superficie come punnizione per la mia disubbidienza, con chiunque mi vorrà seguire."[PARAGRAPH:1]E cosi il Re dei Nani lasciò il Sottosuolo per la prima volta in più 300 anni, allo stesso tempo il clan Fir e i loro alleati partirono per creare la loro nazione Khazad. E cosi i due nani, amici stretti sino ad ora, divennerò accaniti rivali per la maggior parte dell'ultima Era.
TEXT.Spanish: [TAB]Arturus found his friend by candlelight. Torches were forbidden in this hallowed chamber, deep in the Underhome. The soot and smoke they gave off obscured the runes carved into the rows of pillars, covering the names and deeds of the honored Dwarven ancestors. The ancient dwarves who kept these sites, carving new stories and teaching others to read them, were called Runewardens officially but 'Hand Seers' more commonly. Squinting in the candlelight so much invariably robbed them of their sight, so they learned every word and letter by hand. Kandros Fir was at the end of his Clan's section of the Rune Hall, chisel in hand.[PARAGRAPH:1]"I knew I'd find you here," Arturus said, kneeling next to him.[PARAGRAPH:1]"I was his closest kin. I must add his name and deeds to our story."[PARAGRAPH:1]"Of course, old friend. But that isn't all you are planning, is it?" Kandros bowed his head.[PARAGRAPH:1]"I am loyal to our king, by my bones, I am loyal."[PARAGRAPH:1]"But?"[PARAGRAPH:1]"I can no sooner abandon family than fall on my own axe! Suppose your cousin Grunnos was missing. What would you do?"[PARAGRAPH:1]Arturus snorted. "Speak not of that wastrel, but be glad he has many older brothers to be king before him should good Kanlore pass."[PARAGRAPH:1]"But?"[PARAGRAPH:1]"But... were his fate that of Luach, I should dig to Mammon's hell if it would find him. But not if my king forbid it! I know the bonds of kinship, but what of kith? Do you abandon your duty and your friends for a mad search? The winter will take you too, and what will that accomplish?"[PARAGRAPH:1]Kandros rose, placing the hammer and chisel back on the altar as he turned to leave. "My duty has others to attend it, and my friends as well, dear Arturus. But Luach Fir is alone. If our friendship has meaning to you, you will not hinder me."[PARAGRAPH:2]It had not been easy getting to the surface. No one had been allowed to leave since Kandros' cousin Luach had gone to study the surface. Winter still raged, as it had for more than six generations, but young Luach was undaunted, and had petitioned Kanlore for leave to explore the harsh surface regardless of the danger. Supplies were slim in the Underhome. Their stores of black powder had been exhausted so long ago that the last Dwarves who would even recognize it had passed away, and expansion of the Underhome was tedious work with pick and hammer. Spices had run out early in Kandros youth, and the pork and tubers his children fed on left eating a chore. So Luach had at last been allowed to take another appraisal of the state of the bleak surface, but Kanlore's hesitancy had been proven right when Luach did not return for months. No one was permitted to leave now, meaning Kandros had to sneak past guards in the dark, and would be ill regarded if he returned at all.[PARAGRAPH:1]The exit to the Dwarven home was sealed with a massive stone door, and Kandros exhausted himself prying it open, even using his pick as a lever. He bravely stepped from the familiar darkness of his home into the unknown darkness of the Age of Ice. He emerged from the hillside, setting foot on grass. Not snow, and the night air was crisp but lacked the biting chill he had been warned of all his life. He stretched out his arms, marveling at the open space all around, and broke into a run down the hillside. Running was foolhardy in the Underhome. Low ceilings, sharp turns, and sudden drops presented challenges that demanded a careful step, but here there was freedom.[PARAGRAPH:1]And danger. Kandros found himself surrounded by large, grey dogs. He realized he had nearly charged into the den of these animals, and they cared little for his reason for being there. His hand axe was out barely before the first leapt for his throat. It was his blade that found the wolves throat first. And the skull of the next wolf to charge him. He became a whirl of axe and torch until the last beast lay dead or dying.[PARAGRAPH:1]So many animals... how could there be prey enough for a pack of this size in the wasteland he had been lead to believe the surface was? Then he noticed something half buried in the wolves' den. He walked over slowly, pulling the body from the debris, his breath held tight. Unmistakably the body of a dwarf, though it was a gruesome sight to see after the wolves had fed on its flesh. The pattern of the clothing marked it as a clansman of his, and Kandros knew he had found his cousin. He rent his beard and wept over the body. After a time he gathered the gathered up the body, intending to bury it within sight of the Underhome. Then he noticed ... the left shoulder blade was shorn in two. Not broken, but split with a clean cut. He examined it carefully. Luach had been hit from behind by a battle axe, almost certainly by someone of his height.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Murder..." he whispered to the night.[PARAGRAPH:1]He was answered, not by the night, but by a cloaked dwarf holding a Mithril axe directly behind him. "He, like you, wouldn't leave well enough alone, Fir." The dwarf swung his axe for the kill, but then dropped it clumsily and gurgled blood.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Kandros!" Arturus shouted from the entrance of the wolf den, his axe embedded in the neck of the cloaked dwarf. The two friends embraced.[PARAGRAPH:1]"I found Luach, and his killer I think," Kandros informed his friend.[PARAGRAPH:1]Arturus Thorne went pale. "And I found my cousin as well." The dwarf he had killed was the prince Grunnos.[PARAGRAPH:2]The last time Kandros had been in the King's Hall, he had petitioned for permission to search out his cousin. Now, it was with accusation that the King's own son had killed his kin. Were it not for the well respected Arturus beside him, he would have been called a murderer, and worse, a name-killer for making accusations against Grunnos. Kanlore stood from his throne and faced the two Dwarves, his beard reaching nearly his full height. His eldest son and his honor guard flanked him; otherwise the chamber was empty. "You defied the laws of your people, Kandros Fir. The surface world is a harsh land ruled by a dread god and his legion of giants. It was treason to leave."[PARAGRAPH:1]Kandros did not interrupt his king, but rebuked him when he had finished. "The ice is long gone, my liege, and Winter has passed. Your laws made my people's home a prison, and it was based on lies!"[PARAGRAPH:1]"Tis true, uncle," spoke Arturus. "Your scouts have surely misled you for years!"[PARAGRAPH:1]"Not years, foolish Arturus. The ravages of Winter were real enough 10 months ago."[PARAGRAPH:1]"You knew?" gasped Kandros.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Yes, but your cousin had to die to keep this secret. Even with the Winter King gone, the surface world is a vicious realm. Elves and humans wield magic that can destroy any warrior. Greed makes warfare or subjugation unending. Here my people are safe, and here they shall remain."[PARAGRAPH:1]"We are not your children, to be locked away for our own protection. Let the Khazad go forth and prove our worth, not cower in stone chambers like men already dead! You have stolen our spirit, and I name you coward, Kanlore, be it treason or no!"[PARAGRAPH:1]"Enough! Guards, kill them!" The honor guard readied their axes, but looked around, uncertain.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Are you insane, father? These men did no wrong. You did, and you shamed yourself and your kin." Prince Toril sliced off his braided beard and threw it in the king's face. "You shall have no allegiance when word of this perfidy reaches beyond this hall. Nor shall any of your line." The guards heeded his words, and lowered their weapons.[PARAGRAPH:1]"So you too turn. My son, hear this-when the last dwarf is hunted down, felled by lance or wand, be it your name that they curse with their last breath!" Kanlore staggered from the royal hall, towards the surface that he so feared and into exile.[PARAGRAPH:1]The prince turned to Arturus. "Cousin, you are my closest living kin not of my father. It is you the people shall follow."[PARAGRAPH:1]Arturus turned to his old friend. "Kandros, could you not have left this alone as I so asked? Because of you I have become kin-slayer and usurper."[PARAGRAPH:1]"What? This foul scene was Kanlore's doing!"[PARAGRAPH:1]"What I say now I say with heavy heart but the weight of the crown. You sought the surface world, and there you must go, banished from the Underhome. Take provisions, take your clan, take all who would seek their fortune above. This is not justice, but there will not be order in the Underhome while a traitor walks its halls, and you did break the royal decree when you left." Arturus sighed. "As did I, when I followed you. Toril, if you will not be king, then be my viceroy, and I shall take the crown to the surface as punishment for my own disobedience, with whoever will follow me."[PARAGRAPH:1]And so the King of the Dwarves left the Underhome for the first time in over 300 years, and at the same time the Fir clan and their allies parted with their allies to forge their own Khazad nation. The two men who had been closest of fiends grew to be the fiercest of rivals for much of the last Age.

TEXT.English: Auditor Akrus paced steadily down the long, narrow tunnel. It's length seemed pointlessly excessive, and an apparent waste of funding.[PARAGRAPH:1]Looking at it, Akrus couldn't help but sigh and shake his head. He turned to glance at his guide, Thrumbl. A filthy miner who was busy picking things out of his beard. Suppressing a shudder of disgust (thanking Kilmorph that city dwarves were cleaner), Akrus asked the miner where the Foreman was.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Oh, ri't this way, Aud'tor, yur Honour." Thrumbl muttered in a careless dialect.[PARAGRAPH:1]Sighing once more, Akrus followed Thrumbl down the tunnel, visibly dismayed at the lack of work he saw. Only the occasional labourer chatting, lazing around, gambling, and drinking. Nary a pick or worker in sight. After what seemed like an hour of marching, he and Thrumbl emerged from the tunnel into in a large, well lit cavern. It dawned on him where all the workers had been. On scaffolding all around the edge, they were hammering away at the rock walls.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Thar's him, Farman Reorx Veinhunter." Exclaimed Thrumbl, pointing towards the back of the chamber.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Hmph, 'Farman'? Veinhunter? Given what I've seen, he might as well be Reorx Moneywaster", thought Akrus as he strode towards a fairly tall dwarf.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Mr. Veinhunter? I'm Auditor Akrus, it is.good to meet you." He said in a dry voice, noticeably lacking sincerity.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Greetings. Call me Reorx, Auditor. To what do I owe this honour?" The Foreman said in clear, well pronounced Kaz'ak.[PARAGRAPH:1]"No honour in this visit, I'm afraid. Lord Kandros is getting impatient with this dig. You've tunneled miles into the earth, bypassing useful veins of copper I'm told, and for all the funding and men that have been allocated, you've produced nothing in the way of results. I've been ordered to shut down the excavation here, and issue the command to cease work."[PARAGRAPH:1]Reorx only smiled knowingly, raising his arm towards the scaffolding on his far left.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Follow me, Auditor. I've somethin' to show ye that'll make Kandros change his tune right fast"[PARAGRAPH:1]Akrus, frowning, following over to the wall, and climbing haphazardly up the sides of the scaffolding. Workers stepped aside to let them pass as Reorx led the auditor over to a part where the wall had been especially cut in.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Demonstrate to the Auditor what we've got here, lads"[PARAGRAPH:1]Two nearby workers lifted a large pick from the floor, and swung together at the rock wall in front of them. The pick penetrated only a few inches before stopping abruptly. When they wrenched it out again, the head was badly bent.[PARAGRAPH:1]The Auditor's breath caught in his throat as the workers pulled back the thin veneer of rock and dirt, revealing a glimmering silver mass behind, untouched by the impact of the pick.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Foreman Veinhunter", he said in a small voice, full of barely suppressed excitement." is this what I think it is."[PARAGRAPH:1]"Aye, indeed it is. Finest blessings of the goddess in this holy earth"[PARAGRAPH:1]"So this is why the tunnel was so long. But please tell me, how did you know this was here."[PARAGRAPH:1]"Kilmorph told me." Reorx said with a smile[PARAGRAPH:1]And so, Auditor Akrus carried the news back to Kazak, riding a heavily laden cart full of evidence to show to his superiors. Reorx Veinhunter had rewards and titles heaped upon him in abundance, all the empire's available resources at his command, as an army of dwarven workers filled and expanded his new mine. For he had found the largest known vein of Mithril in all of Erebus, and secured the prosperity of Khazak for generations to come.
TEXT.French: L'auditeur Akrus marchait avec précaution droit dans le long tunnel étroit. Sa longueur semblait inutilement excessive, et une apparente dilapidation des fonds.[PARAGRAPH:1]En le regardant, Akrus ne put s'empêcher de soupirer et secouer la tête. Il se tourna pour dévisager son guide, Thrumbl. Un infect mineur occupé à sortir des choses de sa barbe. Retenant un hoquet de dégoût (et remerciant Kilmorph que les villes naines soient plus propres), Akrus demanda au mineur où se trouvait le contremaître.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Oh, l'bas, 'diteur, vot'onneur," murmura Thrumbl dans un dialecte négligé.[PARAGRAPH:1]Soupirant une fois de plus, Akrus suivait Thrumbl dans le tunnel, abasourdi par le manque de travail qu'il pouvait observer. Seuls quelques travailleurs épisodiques, discutant, traînant, pariant, et buvant. Pas une pioche ou un travailleur à l'horizon. Après ce qui avait semblé être une heure de marche, lui et Thrumbl émergèrent du tunnel dans une grande caverne bien éclairée. Il comprit alors où se trouvaient tous les travailleurs. Sur des échafauds tout le long du bord, ils concassaient les murs de roche.[PARAGRAPH:1]"C'lui, Reorx Chassefilon," s'exclama Thrumbl, désignant le fond de la chambre.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Hmpf, Chassefilon ? De ce que je vois, il pourrait bien être Reorx Gâcheargent," pensa Akrus en marchant à grand pas vers un assez grand nain.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Mr Chassefilon ? Je suis l'auditeur Akrus, ravi de vous rencontrer," dit-il d'une voix sèche manquant clairement de sincérité.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Bienvenue. Appelez moi Reorx, Auditeur. Que me vaut cet honneur ?" répondit le contremaître dans un Kaz'ak clair et bien articulé.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Ce n'est pas un honneur, j'en ai bien peur. Le seigneur Kandros s'impatiente avec cette mine. Vous avez creusé des kilomètres sous terre, dépassant les veines utiles de cuivre dont on m'a parlé, et malgré tous les fonds et les hommes alloués, vous n'avez rien produit de ce qui était attendu. J'ai reçu l'ordre de fermer cette excavation, et de faire cesser le travail."[PARAGRAPH:1]Reorx se contenta de sourire d'un air entendu, levant son bras derrière lui vers la gauche.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Suivez-moi, Auditeur. J'ai quequ'chose à v'montrer qui f'ra bien vite l'seigneur Kandros changer d'vis."[PARAGRAPH:1]Akrus, grimaçant de désapprobation, suivit par-dessus le mur, grimpant n'importe comment les tas de gravats. Les travailleurs s'écartèrent pour le laisser passer, tandis que Reorx conduisait l'auditeur vers un pan de mur particulièrement découpé.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Montrez à l'Auditeur ce que nous avons là, les gars."[PARAGRAPH:1]Deux ouvriers proches soulevèrent une grosse pioche, et mirent un grand coup de concert dans le mur en face d'eux. La pioche ne pénétra que de quelques centimètres avant de s'arrêter brusquement. Quand ils l'eurent extraite, sa pointe était fortement tordue.[PARAGRAPH:1]L'auditeur eut le souffle coupé tandis que les ouvriers retiraient la fine couche de pierre et poussière, révélant une masse miroitante d'argent derrière, intacte après l'impact de la pioche.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Contremaître Chasseveine," dit-il d'une petite voix, contenant mal son excitation, "est-ce bien ce que je crois ?"[PARAGRAPH:1]"Yep, bien sûr que c'en est. Le meilleur cadeau de la déesse sur cette terre sacrée."[PARAGRAPH:1]"C'est donc pour ça que le tunnel était si long. Mais dites-moi, comment avez-vous su que c'était là ?"[PARAGRAPH:1]"Kilmorph me l'a dit," répondit Reorx avec un sourire.[PARAGRAPH:1]Ainsi, l'auditeur Akrus rapportait la nouvelle à Kazak, juché sur une charette lourdement chargée de preuves à présenter à ses supérieurs. Reorx Chassefilon reçut des récompenses et des titres en abondance, et toutes les ressources disponibles de l'empire à sa disposition, tandis qu'une armée d'ouvriers nains emplissaient et étendaient sa nouvelle mine. Parce qu'il avait trouvé la plus grande veine de Mithril connue de tout Erebus, et assuré la prospérité de Khazak pour les générations à venir.

TEXT.Italian: Il contabile Akrus camminava con passo sicuro nel tunnel lungo e stretto. La cui lunghezza sembrava inutilmente eccessiva, e un apparente spreco di finanziamenti.[PARAGRAPH:1]Osservandolo, Akrus non potè non sospirare e scutere la testa. Si volto a guardare la sua guida, Thrumbl. Un sudicio minatore che era impegnato a togliersi roba dalla barba. Sopprimendo un brivido di disgusto (ringraziando Kilmorph che i nani di città erano più puliti), Akrus chiese al minatore dove fosse il Caposquadra.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Oh, prorpio da questa parte, Contabile, vostro onore." Thrumbl borbottò in dialetto.[PARAGRAPH:1]Sospirando ancora una volta Akrus seguì Thrumbl lungo il tunnel, rimanendo visibilmente sgomento a causa della mancanza di lavoro che vedeva. Solo qualche manovale occasionale che chiaccherava, oziava, giocava o beveva. Non aveva visto neanche un piccone o un minatore. Dopo ciò che sembrava essere un'ora di marcia, lui e Thrumbl uscirono da tunnel in un grande e ben illuminata caverna. In quel momento si rese conto do dove fossero tutti i minatori. Sulle impalcature tutte intorno al bordo stavano picconando le pareti di roccia.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Eccolo li, Caposquadra Reorx Veinhunter." Esclamo Thrumbl, indicando verso il fondo della caverna.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Hmph, 'Caposquadra'? Veinhunter? Dato ciò che ho visto, potrebbe benissimo essere Reorx Spendaccione", pensò Akrus mentre si dirigeva verso un nano abbastanza alto.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Mr. Veinhunter? Sono il Contabile Akrus, è bello incontrarvi." Disse con voce secca, mancando decisamente di sincerità.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Saluti. Chiamatemi Reorx, Contabile. A cosa devo questo onore?" Il Caposquadra disse in un chiaro e ben pronunciato Kaz'ak.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Nessun onore in questa visita temo. Lord Kandros sta diventando impaziente con questo scavo. Avete scavato kilomentri nella roccia, ignorando delle utili vene di rame per quello che mi è stato detto, e nonostante tutti i finanziamenti e gli uomoni che vi sono stati assegnati non avete portato risultati. Mi è stato ordinato di chiudere gli scavi qui, e di ordinare la cessazione dei lavori."[PARAGRAPH:1]Reorx semplicemente sorrise, alzando il braccio verso le impalcature alla sua sinistra.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Seguitemi, Contabile. Ho qualcosa da mostrarvi che farà cambiare parere rapidamente a Kandros"[PARAGRAPH:1]Akrus, corrucciato, lo seguì fino al muro, per poi salire a caso sulle impalcature. I minatori si fecero da parte per farli passare mentre Reorx guidava il contabile verso una parte in cui il muro era stato particolarmente scavato.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Mostrate al contabile cosa abbiamo qui ragazzi"[PARAGRAPH:1]Due minatori presero da terra un piccone ciascuno e colpirono insieme il muro di roccia davanti a loro. Il piccone penetrò solo di pochi centimetri prima di bloccarsi improvvisamente. Quando lo estrassero la punta era piegata.[PARAGRAPH:1]Al Contabile gli si bloccò il respiro in gola quando i minatori rimossero il sottile strato di roccia e terra, rivelando una lucente massa argentata, senza graffi nonostante l'impatto del piccone.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Caposquadra Veinhunter", disse con una voce bassa, piena di una eccitazione a malapena trattenuta." è ciò che penso che io sia."[PARAGRAPH:1]"Signorsi, lo è. La benedizione più grande della dea in questa sacra terra"[PARAGRAPH:1]"Quindi questo è il motivo della lunghezza del tunnel. Ma vi prego ditemi, come facevate a sapere dove fosse."[PARAGRAPH:1]"Kilmorph me lo ha detto." Reorx disse con un sorriso[PARAGRAPH:1]E cosi, il Contabile Akrus portò la notizia sino a Kazak, guidando un carro pieno di prove da mostrare a suoi superiori. Reorx Veinhunter ricevette ricompense e titoli in abbondanza, e tutte le risorse dell'impero furono messe sotto il suo comando, mentre un esercito di minatori nanici riempiva e ampliava la sua nuova miniera. In quanto lui aveva trovato il filone di Mithril, di cui si aveva conoscenza, più grande di tutto Erebus, e cosi facendo aveva assicurato la prosperità di Khazak per generazioni a venire.

After what seemed like an hour of marching, he and Thrumbl emerged from the tunnel into in a large, well lit cavern. It dawned on him where all the workers had been. On scaffolding all around the edge, they were hammering away at the rock walls.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Thar's him, Farman Reorx Veinhunter." Exclaimed Thrumbl, pointing towards the back of the chamber.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Hmph, 'Farman'? Veinhunter? Given what I've seen, he might as well be Reorx Moneywaster", thought Akrus as he strode towards a fairly tall dwarf.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Mr. Veinhunter? I'm Auditor Akrus, it is.good to meet you." He said in a dry voice, noticeably lacking sincerity.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Greetings. Call me Reorx, Auditor. To what do I owe this honour?" The Foreman said in clear, well pronounced Kaz'ak.[PARAGRAPH:1]"No honour in this visit, I'm afraid. Lord Kandros is getting impatient with this dig. You've tunneled miles into the earth, bypassing useful veins of copper I'm told, and for all the funding and men that have been allocated, you've produced nothing in the way of results. I've been ordered to shut down the excavation here, and issue the command to cease work."[PARAGRAPH:1]Reorx only smiled knowingly, raising his arm towards the scaffolding on his far left.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Follow me, Auditor. I've somethin' to show ye that'll make Kandros change his tune right fast"[PARAGRAPH:1]Akrus, frowning, following over to the wall, and climbing haphazardly up the sides of the scaffolding. Workers stepped aside to let them pass as Reorx led the auditor over to a part where the wall had been especially cut in.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Demonstrate to the Auditor what we've got here, lads"[PARAGRAPH:1]Two nearby workers lifted a large pick from the floor, and swung together at the rock wall in front of them. The pick penetrated only a few inches before stopping abruptly. When they wrenched it out again, the head was badly bent.[PARAGRAPH:1]The Auditor's breath caught in his throat as the workers pulled back the thin veneer of rock and dirt, revealing a glimmering silver mass behind, untouched by the impact of the pick.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Foreman Veinhunter", he said in a small voice, full of barely suppressed excitement." is this what I think it is."[PARAGRAPH:1]"Aye, indeed it is. Finest blessings of the goddess in this holy earth"[PARAGRAPH:1]"So this is why the tunnel was so long. But please tell me, how did you know this was here."[PARAGRAPH:1]"Kilmorph told me." Reorx said with a smile[PARAGRAPH:1]And so, Auditor Akrus carried the news back to Kazak, riding a heavily laden cart full of evidence to show to his superiors. Reorx Veinhunter had rewards and titles heaped upon him in abundance, all the empire's available resources at his command, as an army of dwarven workers filled and expanded his new mine. For he had found the largest known vein of Mithril in all of Erebus, and secured the prosperity of Khazak for generations to come.

TEXT.English: "Every battle leaves behind spoils and soldiers, especially conscripts and mercenaries, are notorious for pilfering the choicest bits before the loot is hauled to the victor's treasury. The Khazad have a very special relationship with wealth and so they have taken measures to prevent its misappropriation after a successful combat: Auditors.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Each auditor is technically a government official and receives a monthly stipend. Because they are well paid, professional soldiers whose peace-time task is keeping the books of Khazad balanced, the auditors are renowned for their post-fighting fastidiousness. With their weather-proof ledgers, individually labeled swag-bags and ax/abacus/slide-rule multi-tool, the auditors ensure that even the smallest skirmish is profitable. Be careful warring with the dwarves for they will strip your warriors of their equipment, weapons, boots, coins and, if necessary, lives.[NEWLINE][BOLD]Rule of Acquisition #34[\BOLD], War is good for business."
TEXT.French: "Chaque bataille laisse derrière elle des restes, et les soldats, particulièrement les conscrits et les mercenaires, sont connus pour dérober les morceaux de choix avant que le butin soit ajouté au trésor du vainqueur. Les Khazadors ont une relation très spéciale avec la richesse et ont ainsi pris des mesures pour éviter ces mauvaises appropriations après un combat victorieux : les Auditeurs.[NEWLINE]Chaque auditeur est techniquement un membre du gouvernement et reçoivent une paye mensuele. Parce qu'ils sont des soldats bien payés dont la tâche en temps de paix est de tenir les livres de comptes khazadors à jour, les auditeurs sont connus pour leur méticulosité d'après-combat. Avec leurs registres imperméables, leurs sacs de butin nommés individuellement leur outil multi-usage hache/abaque/règle, les auditeurs s'assurent que même la plus petite des escarmouches est profitable. Soyez prudent lorsque vous guerroyez avec les nains, sinon ils délesteront vos guerriers de leurs équipements, armes, bottes, pièces et si nécessairesn vies.[NEWLINE][BOLD]Règle de commerce #34[\BOLD], la guerre est bonne pour les affaires."
TEXT.German: "Auf jede Schlacht folgen plündernde Soldaten, besonders Rekruten und Söldner sind bekannt dafür, dass sie sich die besten Stücke herauspicken, bevor die erbeuteten Schätze in der Schatzkammer des siegreichen Herrführers verschwinden. Die Khazad haben eine besondere Einstellung zu Reichtum, und so haben sie Maßnahmen ergriffen, um die ungeordnete Umverteilung nach einem erfolgreichen Kampf zu verhindern: Auditoren.[NEWLINE]Jeder Auditor ist technisch gesehen ein offizieller Vertreter der Regierung und erhält eine monatliche Entschädigung. Da sie gut bezahlt und professionelle Soldaten sind, deren Aufgabe zu Friedenszeiten darin besteht, die Bücher der Khazad zu überprüfen, sind die Auditoren für ihreGründlichkeit und ihren Drang nach Ordnung auch in der Zeit nach den Kämpfen bekannt. Mit ihren wetterfesten Kisten, ihren einzeln gekennzeichneten Sammelbeuteln und ihren Abakus/Rechenschieber-Multifunktionswerkzeugen stellen die Auditoren sicher, dass auch jeder noch so kleine Raubzug profitabel ist. Man sollte allerdings bei Zwergen aufpassen, da sie die eigenen Krieger um ihre Ausrüstung, Waffen, Stiefel, Münzen und, wenn es sein muss, auch um ihre Leben bringen werden.[NEWLINE][BOLD]Regel der Aneignung #34[\BOLD], Krieg ist gut fürs Geschäft."
TEXT.Italian: "Ogni battaglia lascia dietro di se del bottino, e i soldati, specialmente coscritti e mercenari, sono famosi per prendere per se le cose migliori prima di inviare il resto alla tesoreria del vincitore. I Khazad, avendo un rapporto speciale con la ricchezza, hanno adottato misure per prevenire una sua appropriazione indebita dopo la vittoria in combattimento: i Contabili.[NEWLINE]Ogni Contabile è tecnicamente un ufficiale governativo e riceve uno stipendio mensile. Essendo soldati professionisti ben pagati, il cui compito in tempo di pace è di tenere in ordine i libri contabili dei Khazad, i Contabili sono rinomati per la loro meticolosità post-combattimento. Con i loro registri, trattati per resistere alle intemperie, dei sacchi per il bottino etichettati individualmente e la loro piccozza/abaco/righello multiuso i Contabili si assicurano che anche la più piccola delle schermaglie sia redditizia. Fai attenzione quando combatti i nani perché loro spoglieranno i tuoi guerrieri del loro equipaggiamento, delle loro armi, dei loro stivali, delle loro monete e, se necessario, delle loro vite.[NEWLINE][BOLD]Regola di Acquisizione #34[\BOLD], La guerra fa bene agli affari."

TEXT.English: Not to be beaten in the technological arms race concerning their favorite rock-clearing method, the Dwarves have designed their own cannons. Though essentially fulfilling the same purpose as the other races' guns, dwarven cannons are built with dwarven aesthetics in mind: smaller and more compact, yet expertly-crafted and calibrated. These qualities give dwarven cannons an edge over other races' guns; a battery of dwarven cannons can deliver their deadly payloads with great accuracy, wasting less powder and time in bringing down fortifications.
TEXT.French: Pour ne pas être battus dans la course technologique aux armes à propos de leur méthode favorite de nettoyage de rochers, les nains ont conçu leurs propres canons. Bien qu'ils remplissent le même rôle que les 'fusils' des autres races, les canons nains sont construits selon les normes naines : plus petits et compacts, et pourtant construit sans-défaut et parfaitement calibrés. Ces qualités confèrent aux canons nains un avantage sur les 'fusils' es autres races; une batterie de canons nains peut délivrer ses charges utiles mortelles avec une grande précision, gâchant moins de poudre et de temps en destruction de fortifications.

Sebbene ricoprano lo stesso ruolo dei cannoni delle altre razze, i cannoni nanici sono costruiti in stile nanico: più piccoli e compatti degli altri ma comunque sapientemente costruiti e calibrati. Queste qualità danno ai cannoni nanici un vantaggio rispetto a quelli delle altre razze; una batteria di cannoni nanici può sparare con maggiore precisione e consumando meno polvere e tempo nel distruggere le fortificazioni.

TEXT.English: The first generation of Dwarves never age, they are exactly as they were when they were carved, but each generation of dwarves gets a slightly shorter lifespan. As they get farther and farther from the breath of Kilmorph, they become more mortal, in spirit and life. The Dwarven Defenders are drawn from the ranks of the earliest dwarves. Not the very first, for they were few then, but the subsequent generations as they grew and multiplied. Each one has had centuries of training and development in the underhome deeep beneath the earth. Practise daily wearing armour that would crush a mortal man beneath it's weight. Oblivious to the frozen world above, they trained for battle deep within the earth. Though they are not immortal and must die eventually, the Defenders are nevertheless ancient even in dwarven years, and none have yet to die by anything other than a violent means. Now they step forth from their home within the earth, as the Khazad begin the slow but unstoppable Dwarven War March. The Defenders are at the head of the ranks, fearlessly leading the charge into the enemy.
TEXT.French: La première génération de Nains ne vieillit pas, ils restent exactement tels qu'ils furent taillés, mais chaque nouvelle génération de Nains possède une espérance de vie un peu plus courte. Au fur et à mesure qu'ils s'éloignent du souffle de Kilmorph, ils deviennent mortels, physiquement et mentalement. Les Défenseurs Nains sont issus des rangs des premiers Nains. Pas la toute première, qui ne représentait que très peu de Nains, mais des suivantes, tandis qu'ils croissaient et multipliaient. Chacun d'eux s'entraîna pendant des siècles dans le dome souterrain, profondément enterré sous la surface. Ignorant le monde gelé au-dessus d'eux, ils s'entrainèrent au combat loin dans les entrailles d'Erebus. Bien qu'ils ne soient pas immortels et aient toujours un risque de mourir, les Défenseurs sont âgés, même en termes d'années naniques, et aucun n'est décédé autrement que violemment. Aujourd'hui ils marchent depuis leurs maisons souterraines, tandis que les Khazad commencent la lente mais implacable Marche de Guerre Naine. Les Défenseurs sont à la tête de ces rangs, menant sans peur la charge sur les ennemis.
TEXT.German: Die erste Generation der Zwerge altert niemals, sie ist noch genau so, wie sie gemeißelt wurde, aber jede folgende Generation hat eine etwas kürzere Lebensspanne. Je weiter sie sich vom Atem des Kilmorph entfernen, umso sterblicher werden sie, sowohl im Geist wie auch im Körper. Die Zwergenverteidiger rekrutieren sich aus den Reihen der ältesten Zwerge. Nicht aus den allerältesten, aber aus den ersten Nachkommengenerationen. Jeder von ihnen hat Jahrhunderte an Ausbildung und Entwicklung in seinem unterirdischen Heim tief unter der Oberfläche hinter sich. Von der gefrorenen Oberwelt vergessen, haben sie tief in der Erde für die Schlacht trainiert. Obwohl sie nicht unsterblich sind und irgendwann sterben werden, gelten auch die Zwergenverteidiger in Zwergenjahren als uralt, niemand aus ihren Reihen ist allerdings bisher an Altersschwäche gestorben. Nun, da die Khazad ihren langsamen, und doch unaufaltsamen, Kriegsmarsch beginnen, treten sie aus ihren Heimen unter der Erde, und begeben sich in die ersten Reihen, um den Kampf absolut furchtlos zum Feind zu tragen.
TEXT.Italian: La prima generazione di Nani non invecchiano, rimangono esattamente uguali a come quando erano stati scolpiti, ma ogni generazione successiva ha una durata della vita leggermente minore. Man mano che si allontanano dal respiro di Kilmorph diventano sempre più mortali, nella vita e nello spirito. I Difensori Nanici sono composti dai nani delle prime generazioni. Non la prima generazione perché erano pochi allora, ma da quelle successive quando crescevano e si moltiplicavano. Ognuno di loro ha con se secoli di addestramento e di sviluppo passati nel Sottosuolo. Ignari del mondo ghiacciato di sopra, si sono addestrati per combattere in profondità della terra. Anche se non sono immortali e moriranno eventualmente, i Difensori sono comunque antichi anche in anni nanici, e nessuno è ancora morto se non in modo violento. Ora stanno uscendo dalla loro casa sotto terra, mentre i Khazad iniziano la lenta, ma inarrestabile, Marcia da Guerra Nanica. I Difensori sono in prima linea, guidando senza paura gli assalti contro i nemici.
